ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot very fast  intense
I improved my knowledge of French. This class focused mainly on reading skills, expanding vocabulary, and elaborating on the minutiae of grammar.
I reinforced my French immensely throughout the course. It teaches so much grammar, but it became easier to understand books and even films after each unit.
Beginning introduction to literature in French as well as continued study of grammar and word forms
Better understanding of all the different types of grammar, and I really thought that I improved in my knowledge of how to say different things in different situations.
A continuation of L1 and L2 French with expanded vocabulary and grammar. Involved reading novels, watching films, and speaking and writing about them.

I developed new study skills in order to prepare for audio, memory, oral, and written testing. these study skills that I acquired of meeting with my teacher, studying with classmates, using a peer tutor, and using french youtube to explain things are skills that I can take with me towards future courses. I also developed a deeper knowledge of french culture across many french speaking countries whereas my knowledge of french culture was previously limited to just france.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths; makes you learn French very quickly 

Weaknesses: soooo much work

I think the approach of expanding through reading texts worked really well. Connecting vocabulary to a narrative and to a greater context beyond a simple definition really helped me remember the words and seeing grammatical constructions being used helped me to better understand and remember how they work. 

One weakness is that I didn't feel like I got as much practice with speaking French. There was a lot less opportunity to speak in class in this class than in the previous two levels of French at Yale, and I don't feel like my speaking skills improved very much even though I'm certain that my reading skills have.

I think all FREN courses (at least in my experience) are very heavy workload-wise, but I feel like the amount of work can sometimes take away from my ability to process the new things we learn in class.

The one thing I believe could be improved is the manner in which quizzes are administered. I think it would cause much less stress on the students' end if we were warned about being tested on a certain grammar concept a day in advance.

Strengths: Madame Koizim is an absolutely amazing professor, she teaches in a very clear manner and is almost always accessible by email if there are any questions. 

Point of improvement: although I really enjoyed the class, 2 hours of homework every night on top of meeting everyday was a bit excessive. I do recognize that this allowed my French to flourish, however.

Strengths: Professor absolutely AMAZING!!!! Get to know classmates relatively well. Professor really understanding if students get sick, need a mental health break, etc. 
Weaknesses: Was online, so some of the speaking portions of the participation felt like it wasn't able to come out as naturally as it could've been in person (but the reasons I COMPLETELY understand why it was online, and I'm glad it was)

This course is a lot of work with at least a few hours of homework each night and tests every few weeks. It is very strong in reinforcing the language, but speaking practice can be lacking in a class larger than 8 students. There is a lot that is covered between grammar, vocabulary, writing, speaking, listening, and reading French, and it is a credit to the course that each of these things is taught extensively.

The strengths of this course are how much students are able to speak during each class and how much grammar we learn and are able to apply. Another huge strength is how much Madame Koizim cares about her students and how available she makes herself to help everyone. One of the weaknesses would be the pop quizzes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are passionate about improving your French

I would totally recommend this course. I believe the amount of work was hard to get used to at first, but all the practices and all the readings we do definitely helped my understanding of the language.
Yes, I would recommend taking this class specifically with Madame Koizim if possible. Just be prepared for the huge time commitment that this class requires in order to do well.

YES!!! Thought I would just say in general, language classes are really catered to specific people. If you don't even like learning language, then taking any language class might not be really interesting. However, Madame Koizim, is SUPER ENERGETIC and ALWAYS makes learning French really interesting and engaging. So, honestly, if you don't even like learning French, this would be the perfect class to take just because the Professor is so great at keeping uninterested students somehow interested :)

Yes! Taking this course means a student will learn mass amounts of grammar and be able to implement it so soon. A student will also learn so much about french culture, and will get to read so many interesting stories and watch really good movies.
